bibl.title: Monthly Progress Report to the Surgeon General, U.S. Public Health Service, by Lunsford D. Fricks, June 5, 1924

div1.p: Fricks reports on malaria investigations in the southern United States. He details laboratory work, epidemiological studies, and impounded water investigations.

div1.head: Monthly Progress Report to the Surgeon General, U.S. Public Health Service, by Lunsford D. Fricks, June 5, 1924
div1.opener:
Mal
Report
C O P Y
Hdq: Field Investigations of Malaria,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Room 17, Court House,
Memphis, Tennessee.
June 5, 1924.
FB
----
Monthly Progress Report,
May, 1924.
The Surgeon-General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Division of Scientific Research,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to forward herewith monthly progress
report of malaria investigations conducted during the month
of May, 1924, under the direction of this office.

Field Laboratory, Crowley, Louisiana: Personnel - Special
Expert M. A. Barber and Assoc. San. Eng. W. H. W. Komp.

Activities at the Crowley Laboratory consisted of: (1) Exper-
iments on staining methods for malaria plasmodia; (2) Effect
on Anopheles larvae of the hydrogen-ion concentration of the
water in which they are breeding; (3) Observations on larval
food; (4) Observations on incidence of Anopheles, largely pro-
duced in rice fields; bred out from larvae or pupae A. quad-
rimaculatus 61, A. crucians 221; collected imago stage A.
quadrimaculatus 851; A. crucians 632, A. walkeri two; (5) Blood
specimens examined for malaria parasites: school children 107,
of which four were positive, P. vivax, three P. falciparum;
physicians' specimens examined 27, of which seven were positive,
P. vivax, one P. falciparum; reexamination of positives in 1923
three, of which one was positive, P. falciparum.

Memphis Laboratory: Personnel - A. A. Surgeon Wm. A. Krauss,
Microscopists Ethel Barrier and Retha Kitchens.

798 blood smears examined for malaria parasites, of which 540
were collected from school children in Chatham County, Georgia,
seven of these positive, P. vivax, six positive, P. falciparum;
82 collected from Leflore County, Mississippi, of which one was
positive P. vivax, two positive P. falciparum; five specimens
sent in from Tennessee State Board of Health, of which two were
Monthly Progress Report
-2-
June 5, 1924.
positive, P. vivax; 231 specimens were sent in locally, of which
29 were positive P. vivax, eleven positive, P. falciparum, and
two found with double infection.

Field Laboratory, Savannah, Georgia: Personnel - Technical
Asst. Bruce Mayne.

Activities at this laboratory consisted of: (1) Observations on
incidence of Anopheles; collected in imago stage A. quadrimacula-
tus males four, females 21, A. crucians males 19, females 261,
habitat of these mosquitoes as follows: animal sheds A. crucians
203, A. quadrimaculatus 7; lumber-camp bunk-houses A. crucians
51, A. quadrimaculatus 15; under school houses and out houses
A. crucians 22, A. quadrimaculatus three; inside residences A.
crucians four; no adult punctipennis encountered; 51 specimens of
A. crucians were taken from human habitations; (2) 56 specimens
A. crucians and eight A. quadrimaculatus were dissected, none
found infected; (3) Effect of drying of Anopheles' eggs of A.
crucians were found to hatch after being removed 24 days from
water; (4) 84 blood specimens collected locally were examined
for malaria parasites, of which two were found positive, P.
vivax.

Epidemiological Studies of Malaria: Personnel - Asst. Surgeon
F. F. Maxcy.

Dr. Maxcy's activities consisted of; (1) Malaria surveys around
six saw mills in Clark and Baldwin Counties; study being made of
Anopheles production and effect of screening and quinine in con-
trolling malaria among saw mill employees (in conjunction with
Asst. San. Eng. J. C. Carter); (2) malaria surveys of two saw
mills in Barbour County; (3) Continued the collection and analy-
sis of malaria mortality figures from all of the Southern States.

Impounded Waters in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Epidemiolo-
gist T. H. D. Griffitts and Asst. San. Eng. E. H. Gage.

Dr. Griffitts' (Alabama) activities consisted of: (1) Inspection
of Golden Bridge Pond, May 1-3, five A. punctipennis and two A.
crucians developed from larvae collected, no house infestation
observed; (2) Inspection of Gambusia hatcheries Cherokee Basin,
Tallapoosa County, May 5-9; 24 ponds were created, four found
dry, sixteen contained gambusia, some well stocked, fourteen of
these were producing Anopheles; (No mention made by Dr. Griffitts
of size of larvae or condition of vegetation); all mosquitoes
which emerged from larvae and pupae collected in fish ponds were
A. punctipennis; (3) Inspection of recently impounded pond near
Gantt's Qarry, Talladega County; recommendations made for mosqui-
to control; (4) Inspection of mosquito control around Veterans'
Monthly Progress Report
-3-
June 5, 1924.
Bureau Hospital, Lake City, Florida, May 14-16; recommendations
submitted to Medical Officer in Charge; May 20-23 drainage sur-
vey made at Selma, Dallas-County; recommendations submitted for
antimalaria campaign.

Mr. Gage (South Carolina). Mr. Gage's activities consisted of
observations on incidence of Anopheles in Horse Creek Valley,
Aiken County, South Carolina: marked increases in all forms of
aquatic life; maximum water temperature 82 degrees; approximate-
ly three times as many Anopheles larvae taken per average dip as
were taken in April; six times as many adult Anopheles were found
per resting place examined as were found in April, the proportions
being A. crucians 57%, A. punctipennis 41%, and A. quadrimaculatus
2%; the proportion of emergence from larvae collected A. crucians
54%, A. punctipennis 44%, and A. quadrimaculatus 2%, the latter
from a seepage area; Anopheles larvae three times as abundant in
producing areas other than impounded waters and four times as
many adult Anopheles were found per resting place away from imp-
ounded water projects as in resting places adjacent to these ponds.

Major Drainage in Relation to Malaria: Assoc. San. Eng. A. W.
Fuchs.

Mr. Fuchs' activities consisted of: Malaria surveys of North Little
Rock, Arkansas, at the request of Mr. Van Hovenberg and in support
of anti-malaria program of the Missouri Pacific Railway; collec-
tion of drainage data from the Mississippi Delta Counties from
Bureau of Candus; study made of plan through which the agricultur-
al agent of Shelby County, Tennessee, cooperating with the County
health officials proposes to score communities doing mosquito con-
trol and award prizes at the Tri-State Fair; advice and assistance
furnished.

Rural Malaria Investigations: Personnel - A.A. Surgeon C.P. Coogle,
Asst. San. Eng. J.C. Carter, Assoc. San. Eng. L.M. Fisher, Asst. San.
Eng. J. G. Foster, Asst. San. Eng. H. N: Old, Asst. San. Eng. F. R.
Shaw, and Surgeon L.L. Williams.

Mr. Carter's (Alabama) activities consisted of study of rural mal-
aria control in Clark, Baldwin, Barbour, Houston, and Dallas
Counties; surveys made around five saw mills in Clarke County show-
ed high incidence of malaria, with mosquito control economically
impossible; effort made to interest mill operators in screening
and quinine administration; Malaria surveys made around saw mills
in Baldwin County, malaria foci located and plotted on county map;
similar malaria surveys made of two saw mills in Barbour County;
screen surveys continued in Houston County; malaria school survey
completed in Dallas County.
Monthly Progress Report

Mr. Old (Georgia) activities consisted of study of mal-
aria mosquito conditions continued in Chatham County;
(1) Adult Anopheles collected as follows: 80 observations
made, five of which were in occupied houses, others out
houses and bridges, A. crucians collected, males 36, females
758, A. quadrimaculatus males four, females 17; the five
occupied houses gave 29 A. crucians females and one A. quad-
rimaculatus male; (2) Emergence from larvae collected: A.
crucians male 20, females 20, A. quadrimaculatus female one,
A. punctipennis female one; (3) Observations go to show that
Anopheles producing areas in Chatham County are purely local
and not wide spread; in many parts of the County Anopheles
are rarely seen;, (4) Observations of drainage ditch mainte-
nance and methods of removing vegetation therefrom contin-
ued; (5) Observations conducted of malaria conditions around
three lumber camps; (6) Study of bamboo for sub-soil drainage
undertaken.

Mr. Shaw (Louisiana) activities consisted of rural malaria
control investigations in Tangipahoa and St. Mary's Parishes:
Study made of screening situation in Tangipahoa Parish; stu-
dy of quinine administration by Natalbany Lumber Company con-
tinued; of 376 adult A. quadrimaculatus and 546 A. crucians
collected in out houses only three were males; anophelines larvae
very scarce and difficult to find; malaria school census com-
pleted in St. Mary's Parish; malaria lecture delivered at three
rural schools; tide levee and tide gate study being made at
Patterson; study of method by which water temperature in metal
cisterns may be reduced.

Dr. C. P. Coogle and Asst. San. Eng. J. G. Foster, activities
consisted of malaria and mosquito studies in Leflore County
continued: weekly inspection of mosquito resting places; 263
adult Anopheles collected, A. quadrimaculatus 24 male, 175
female, A. punctipennis ten male, 53 female, A. crucians one
female; gradual, uniform increase in Anopheles noted; a marked
decrease in adult catches noted for two days after each heavy
rain; diligent search made for Anopheles larvae; apparently
much more rare than adults; emergences of larvae collected, all
A. punctipennis; 50 tenant houses selected for screening studies.

Mr. Fisher (South Carolina), activities consisted of rural
malaria control investigations continued in counties having
health organizations; malaria school census completed in
eighteen counties; mosquito survey made at Chester, South
Carolina.
Monthly Progress Report

Surgeon L. L. Williams (Virginia) activities consisted of
locating malaria foci and mosquito producing areas and de-
termining the relative importance of A. punctipennis, A.
crucians and A. quadrimaculatus in conveying malaria in
Virginia; only A. punctipennis and A. crucians emerged from
larvae collected during May; mosquito production definitely
began in all breeding areas under observation the last week
in May.

Conferences and Inspections: Senior Sanitary Engineer J. A.
LePrince visited Field Laboratory at Crowley, Louisiana, May
1st; Inspection at Franklin, La. May 2nd; Inspection of
Shelby county rural malaria control May 6-12th, apparently
adult Anopheles not yet emerged in this locality; inspection
Leflore County, Mississippi, May 19-22; inspection Columbia,
South Carolina, May 28-31; prepared paper for International
Conference of Sanitary Engineers at London, England; prepared
paper for International Health Conference on Health Problems,
at Kingston, Jamaica, B.W.I.

Medical Officer in Charge attended conference of field direc-
tors, Scientific Research Division, Washington,, D.C., May 7th;
attended the Mississippi Medical Association, Jackson, Miss.,
May 14th-15th; conference with Dr. W. V. King, Bureau of En-
tomology, Mound, La., May 17th.

Expenditures: During the month approximately $4,637.52 was
expended from the Malaria Allotment in connection with field
investigations of malaria.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon,
Medical Officer in Charge.
